comments.commentBody:
I had to back and look at 10D - because I'd filled in 9A, 16A, and 18A, I never noticed it. There's no way that I would have put in CAN - I would have thought that " "pokey" was an adjective - clever clue. so was "powerful ray" and "places to get Reubens".

New word: EVERSO - oh no!!! I didn't see that it's two words!!! I guess I need a joke on me once in a while! I don't think I'm ready to go to the ACPT yet.

Thanks for the fun, Carolyn and Will.
11:04 pm

So what brings out the memories in today’s puzzle? Of course you have memories when you are long in the tooth. Is it the theme? My Dad always drank tea and never coffee. Is it RABBIT EARS because those were the only antennas for the early TVs? Is it the LEM because I remember what I was doing when Neil Armstrong stepped onto the moon? Is it those DELIS in Shaker Heights where my wife would order a Reuben?

No.

It’s the Greyhound BUS. When many kids would go off to camp for the summer, I would travel to Paducah to stay with my grandmothers, aunts and uncles and cousins for most of the summer. I actually had a group of kids who were my summer playmates in Paducah. As a kid I traveled to Paducah and back to Chicago on the Greyhound BUS. Those were the days before air conditioning. The ride was long, by way of US 45, not Interstate 57. The ride from Chicago to Paducah was 400 miles, with almost nothing but cornfields to watch out the window. The time was invariably 8 long, boring, hot hours. I used to imagine that the driver was driving around the same cornfield for 8 hours band then we were magically there.

It was also a time of segregation, with separate restrooms in the bus station. Once, on the way to Paducah, the bus stopped at the old Irvin S. Cobb Bridge that crossed the Ohio River so that African-Americans would go to the rear, as required by Kentucky law. Those were the days before Rosa Parks. Those days are now a distant memory.

Racer19@39: de nada.
and JaneC@43: yep, it's a genuine unrehearsed classic. Johnny was really quick with the wit on that one.

Massage? Moi? I don't know what you're talking about.{Looking innocent} She *did* push him. Gently.

What Amy said. The field *is* male-dominated. As for the plotting, that takes place only after the first course.

Mr. Libertarian1: Deb Amlen is a humorist. She may at times massage a story for humorous effect. I assure you that no violence occurred at the gathering in question. It's more boring to say "He asked if he could join us and one woman told him 'no,'" isn't it?

And listen, there have been plenty of male-only crossword gatherings. They're not trying to be male-only, it just happens that way because the field is male-dominated. If female constructors don't want to be outnumbered by men to the tune of a 70/30 split, yes, we'll darn well get together for an hour every year. (And yes, we'll be plotting against you, just as you might suspect.)

JolleyGood@15 and Tudor@29 and Deb:  this theme is worse than eating peanuts.  *A*A where the asterisk is replaced by C or K ishows up slightly altered in the very respectable word cacophony, which literally means "crappy sounds".   And I am really surprised no one brought up the cruci-popular RARA avis ... indeed

Hey, that's a good lookin' shoe... do you have it in a size 14?

(and what did you do with the rights?)

Thanks for the mind workout!

Massage? Moi? I don't know what you're talking about.{Looking innocent} She *did* push him. Gently.

What Amy said. The field *is* male-dominated. As for the plotting, that takes place only after the first course.
58A is clued wrong.  The clue should be: what do sad teachers produce?  Answer:  RABBI TEARS.

In this entire discussion, does anyone remember the days of patronage, when entire administration from the lowest clerk to the secretary to the Governor were, upon election, dismissed en masse and replaced by those who the newly elected Govenor owed favors????????  This is why we have civil services employment acts and collective bargaining agreements.  The Civil Service, state or Federal, performs an invaluable service, especially during times of transition.  That service is maintaining administrative equilibrium in the government while the new administration learns the ropes.  In face, new administrations learn the ropes from guess who, civil servants.  Given whats taking place in the world right this moment, what price can you put on organizational homeostasis??  Thanks to Scott Walker, the next step for civil service is to fight for their fate, and organize to create a separate but equal branch of government.  Call it the Bureaucracy or whatever, but it is time to draw a bright line in the sand between ambitious puerile politicians in the pockets of the Koch Brothers and defend the civil service which day in and day out defends us, all of us, against them.  The Civil Service is the last line of defense between order and utter chaos.
Yes but did they poll folks who actually VOTE.

The union workers make more than I do, get better benefits & don't work half as hard.  You bet my state needs to cut union benefits & even moreso, cut the number of workers.  I voted fir the governor & would do so again!
What were the EXACT poll questions provided for the poll?
Government giveth, and government taketh away. And in the case of Tea Party / Republican American, that means tax breaks for the wealthy and pay cuts for the working poor.
Maybe it's time to resurrect the union enthusiasm/and songs of Woody Guthrie & Pete Seeger as a rallying call.  Let's not forget the past!

Although I have reservations about any public employee retiring before age 62 (police and fire can work desk jobs when they get older, etc) and I object to full funded pensions and health care benefits when no body else gets them ( but will be expected to pay for them for government workers), I think there is pure politics in the position to end collective bargaining especially when the unions are prepared to concede some benefits in these hard times.

So appropos, today while reading over a thousand news articles for a research project I came across an article in the New York Times, August 8, 1859. The story was regarding journeymen bakers who were organizing for collective bargaining. The issue was their belief that a 20 hour work day, out of 24, was too long. They believed that a 12 hour workday was more acceptable.

Elimination of the right to bargain collectively will revisit the same work conditions of the past. Think it can't happen here? This article shows it can and it has.

What's so unusual?  It's the same old story of government attempting to  fix the problems of waste and corruption on the backs of its citizens!  Bravo to the Republicans for trying to rid the world of that evil, selfish practice..."collective bargaining".

The Koch Brothers and their lapdog Scott Khadafi Walker are laughing their heads off knowing they've succeeded in pitting workers against each other!

Can we please drop the prefixes "public" and "private" for just a second and concentrate on who the real enemy is for a change. In the end we're all workers!
How can reader #158 even say such things?

The upheavels in the Middle East are largely due to the severe economic inequality between the few haves and the many have-nots. Here in the US, our loudest protest group is the Tea Party, which wants the already obscenely rich to get even more- why?- because they can. Face it, Americans will never "walk like an Egyptian". To be an American is to worship the rich- far more than the British ever worshiped any King. The rich know that downtrodden Americans may talk about how bad things are- but they will never actually do anything about it. When push comes to shove, they will always come running to the wealthy- for crumbs and the increasingly meager offerings their very sporadic sense of pity will allow. Observing former middle-class Americans is as sad as watching neutered sheep.

So it's the public sector who are greedy for wanting to keep a living wage and health care benefits for their families while, what is that you say? People in the private sector are accepting wage freezes and benefits cuts?  Do the good people at Goldman Sachs getting their average annual $1M bonus know that's what they're supposedly doing?  How about those bravehearts at Google who have had to make do with only a 10% bonus for EVERY employee plus a correspondent salary increase this year?  My heart bleeds for them, it really does.  And good old Charlie Sheen, outraged that he's only paid $2M per episode vs. the $3M he feels he really deserves.  Not to mention Bank of America which paid not one red cent of taxes last year, despite being bailed out with my and your hard earned money that WE paid in taxes.  But I digress... Of course it's the public sector -- the teachers, nurses, cops, firefighters, law clerks, EMTS, construction workers, etc who are the American people's enemies.  "They" want to bleed us all dry -- yeah right!!!  You pawns of the corporate-fawning right are sickening and you'll sell your fellow man out as fast as you can for a groveling word of approval from Newtie or John-Boehn... You should be ashamed of yourselves.

It doesn't really matter much at this point what people want or don't want. How things will play out will be determined almost entirely by $14T debt and $1.5T continuous deficits.
It won't be pretty.

Americans claim to want all kinds of things because forever they've simply borrowed whatever it cost without paying it back.  The reality check is here.  Handing out fish rather than teaching folks how to fish is a (irresponsible) "luxury" we can no longer afford.  Unions - collectives that originally fought oppression - long ago were corrupted as coercive instruments for soliciting freebies from politicians who profited personally, becoming havens for those who could not on their own compete on level fields with the rest of us.  The era of unions coincides with the decline of productivity and erudition in the United States.  What other metric does one need to pass judgement on the matter in Wisconsin, or any other involving a labor union?

I am sorry but I have been a member of a labor union, and believe me they hurt more than they help. I worked on a nuclear poject and the contractors were paid by the bodies on the job whether or not we had anything to do that day.  I remember sitting in a pipe yard under a tarp playing cards and reading earning time and a half because we did not have anything to do that day due to lack of materials on the job site.  I believe unions had their place at one time, but I believe their time has past.  In the past employers made too many concessions to the unions and unions do not give back when times get hard.  The older members do not care about the younger members only maintaining the status quo for themselves.

Re: comment #38/Kathie - thanks!  You put that beautifully!  I will always support others efforts to obtain a decent standard of living.  How could I call myself an American and a supporter of our Declaration of Independence if I did not?
